dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been hearing a lot about security tokens, right? This idea of turning traditional assets, like real estate or company stock, into digital stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been hearing a lot about security tokens, right? This idea of turning traditional assets, like real estate or company stock, into digital stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The market for security tokens, or traditional securities turned into digital assets, is quiet The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, totally! I remember the buzz, like, "This is the next big crypto thing!" Everyone was saying it'd make things super liquid and easy to trade. [overlaps] Conferences even!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, totally! I remember the buzz, like, "This is the next big crypto thing!" Everyone was saying it'd make things super liquid and easy to trade. Conferences even!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto. Conferences sprung up entirely focused on security tokens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And, um, the theory made total sense. Digital versions of paper documents, more portable, more demand. But fast forward a year and a half... and, well, progress has been a *bit* different.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And, um, the theory made total sense. Digital versions of paper documents, more portable, more demand. But fast forward a year and a half... and, well, progress has been a bit different.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The underlying idea made sense... But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh? How so? I mean, I haven't heard as much noise lately. Is it, like, not happening?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh? How so? I mean, I haven't heard as much noise lately. Is it, like, not happening?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, according to Blocksmith, a company that helps mint these coins, less than five security tokens have actually been *created*. But here's the wild part: the few that exist? They're actually super liquid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, according to Blocksmith, a company that helps mint these coins, less than five security tokens have actually been created. But here's the wild part: the few that exist? They're actually super liquid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More than 100 security tokens have been created, according to Polymath, a startup that helps companies mint coins. But theyre not liquid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, less than *five*? That's insane! But then, how can they be 'super liquid' if there are so few? Where are people even trading them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, less than five? That's insane! But then, how can they be 'super liquid' if there are so few? Where are people even trading them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a weird one. In the U.S., there are only two exchanges. Openfinance, for example, trades over 500 assets – they estimate over $100 million in daily transactions! Tzero, though, only trades its own token.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a weird one. In the U.S., there are only two exchanges. Openfinance, for example, trades over five hundred assets - they estimate over one hundred million dollars in daily transactions! Tzero, though, only trades its own token.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.S., just two exchanges exist where these assets trade, and volume is tiny. Openfinance trades only four assets with daily transactions of less than $1 million a day, we estimate. Overstocks Tzero exchange trades a single asset, its own Tzrop token.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, okay. So the existing ones are busy. But if the idea is so good, and there's liquidity, why aren't more popping up? What's the holdup?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, okay. So the existing ones are busy. But if the idea is so good, and there's liquidity, why aren't more popping up? What's the holdup?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mostly, um, regulation. It's a huge hurdle. For a company to set up a trading venue here, they have to register with the SEC as a broker-dealer, get an exchange license, or an ATS, which is, like, a really long and costly process.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mostly, um, regulation. It's a huge hurdle. For a company to set up a trading venue here, they have to register with the S E C as a broker-dealer, get an exchange license, or an A T S, which is, like, a really long and costly process.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many of the barriers to adoption are regulation-related. For U.S. companies to build a trading venue for security tokens, they must register as a broker-dealer with the SEC and get a license for either an exchange or an alternative trading system (ATS), which requires a long and costly process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the red tape. And I also read about those holding periods, too. Like, once a new security is bought, it can't change hands for a whole year? That can't help with liquidity, can it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the red tape. And I also read about those holding periods, too. Like, once a new security is bought, it can't change hands for a whole year? That can't help with liquidity, can it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Holding periods are also a delaying factor: After a brand new security is formed and purchased by an initial buyer, it typically cant change hands for a year due to regulations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope, definitely not for immediate trading. But Josh Stein from Smart Valor, he talks about the *potential* – imagine a global IPO! U.S. investors investing in Mumbai companies as easily as New York ones. That's, uh, the dream.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope, definitely not for immediate trading. But Josh Stein from Smart Valor, he talks about the potential - imagine a global I P O! U.S. investors investing in Mumbai companies as easily as New York ones. That's, uh, the dream.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In theory, security tokens could allow for a global IPO, says Olga Feldmeier, founder and CEO of Swiss security token exchange Smart Valor.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That sounds amazing, but also incredibly complex, right? All these different countries would need to agree on, like, a common framework. That's a huge ask.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That sounds amazing, but also incredibly complex, right? All these different countries would need to agree on, like, a common framework. That's a huge ask.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. He points out Switzerland can already do securities settlement on the blockchain, but in the U.S., it's all through NASDAQ, 90 million transactions a day. Very different systems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. He points out Switzerland can already do securities settlement on the blockchain, but in the U.S., it's all through N A S D A Q, ninety million transactions a day. Very different systems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, in Switzerland, securities settlement can already happen on the blockchain, Feldmeier says. In the U.S., its controlled by the DTCC, a New Jersey clearinghouse that handles 90 million transactions daily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's not just about, you know, slapping a token on something and calling it a day. Olga Feldmeier from Harbor says people realized 'yelling the word token' isn't a substitute for a good investment strategy or distribution channels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's not just about, you know, slapping a token on something and calling it a day. Olga Feldmeier from Harbor says people realized 'yelling the word token' isn't a substitute for a good investment strategy or distribution channels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Josh Stein, CEO of San Francisco security token platform Harbor, agrees. People have realized that yelling the word token is not a substitute for a good investment or distribution channels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But there are success stories. Harbor, for instance, helped with a $20 million offering, and now Rhodium Capital is using them for $100 million in real estate. So, it *is* happening in targeted ways.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But there are success stories. Harbor, for instance, helped with a twenty million dollar offering, and now Rhodium Capital is using them for one hundred million dollars in real estate. So, it is happening in targeted ways.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In April, a $20 million security token offering led by Harbor was canceled after the participating real estate firm, Convexity Properties, couldnt get favorable terms on the loan it was using to finance the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, that's promising. But, like, some people still have doubts, right? The long-term benefits are still kinda dubious for some. [interrupts] I think the Polymath CEO even said their new blockchain would be *worse* than Ethereum.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that's promising. But, like, some people still have doubts, right? The long-term benefits are still kinda dubious for some. I think the Polymath C E O even said their new blockchain would be worse than Ethereum.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Polymath CEO Trevor Koverko believes his companys new blockchain will provide better security than Ethereumthe platform where most security tokens live todayand will boost adoption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he did. But then you have others, like Fred Schebesta, who see the huge advantage in slower settlement for banking transactions, where multiple parties can use the same ledger. Eliminates all that back-and-forth messaging.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he did. But then you have others, like Fred Schebesta, who see the huge advantage in slower settlement for banking transactions, where multiple parties can use the same ledger. Eliminates all that back-and-forth messaging.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fred Schebesta, founder of Australian comparison site Finder and cofounder of crypto exchange HiveEx, says that faster settlement for banking transactions is the most important feature, since multiple parties can plug into the same shared ledger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it seems like a mixed bag right now, but with some serious potential. What's the short-term outlook?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it seems like a mixed bag right now, but with some serious potential. What's the short-term outlook?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Philippe Bekhazi from XBTO thinks we'll see significant changes in six months. And Josh Stein believes it'll take about six months to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure needed. So, if regulators get on board, investors are gonna be thrilled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Philippe Bekhazi from X B T O thinks we'll see significant changes in six months. And Josh Stein believes it'll take about six months to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure needed. So, if regulators get on board, investors are gonna be thrilled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A year from now, well be in about the same place, said Philippe Bekhazi, CEO of crypto trading firm XBTO, at the Consensus conference last week. Smart Valors Olga Feldmeier thinks it will take five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure necessary for security tokens to trade across nearly every country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Fingers crossed then! Sounds like we'll have to keep an eye on those regulatory shifts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fingers crossed then! Sounds like we'll have to keep an eye on those regulatory shifts.
